name: Bilbao
fun_fact: Fun fact: The pintxo (Basque tapas) bar crawl called 'txikiteo' is a Bilbao tradition where locals hop from bar to bar on Friday and Saturday nights - but unlike typical pub crawls, the focus is equally on the artful, bite-sized pintxos as it is on drinking, creating a social dining ritual unique to Basque Country.

hero_dishes.name: Gilda
hero_dishes.description: The original pintxo created 60+ years ago - a simple skewer with Spanish chili pepper (guindilla), an olive, and an anchovy. Briny, spicy, perfect.
hero_dishes.origin_story: Named after Rita Hayworth's character in the 1946 film 'Gilda,' this pintxo is 'green, salty, and a little spicy' - just like the femme fatale. The Gilda bar in Bilbao specializes in this classic, offering 19 different variations.
hero_dishes.where_to_find: Gilda (modern pintxos bar specializing in this classic), Cafe Bar Bilbao (classic pintxos since 1879)

hero_dishes.name: Bacalao al Pil Pil
hero_dishes.description: Salt cod cooked in olive oil with garlic and chili peppers, creating a thick, emulsified sauce through technique alone (no cream or flour).
hero_dishes.origin_story: A Basque culinary masterpiece that showcases technique over ingredients. The sauce forms from the cod's gelatin emulsifying with olive oil, creating a creamy texture through gentle swirling. It's cooking as chemistry and art.
hero_dishes.where_to_find: Rio Oja (classical Basque restaurant specializing in traditional cod), traditional Basque restaurants throughout Bilbao

hero_dishes.name: Txuleta (Basque Steak)
hero_dishes.description: Locally sourced beef, grilled over charcoal to perfection. The Basque cut and preparation emphasize the quality of the meat.
hero_dishes.origin_story: Basque Country takes beef seriously - the local cattle breeds and grilling techniques create steaks that rival anywhere in the world. It's about respecting the ingredient and the fire.
hero_dishes.where_to_find: Asador Etxebarri (30 minutes from Bilbao in Axpe, world-renowned for grilling), traditional asadores

hero_dishes.name: Idiazabal Cheese Soup at Gure Toki
hero_dishes.description: Award-winning soup featuring the nutty, smoky sheep's milk cheese from the Basque region.
hero_dishes.origin_story: Gure Toki's signature dish showcases Idiazabal, a Basque PDO cheese traditionally smoked over hawthorn or cherry wood. This soup won awards for elevating a traditional cheese into contemporary pintxo culture.
hero_dishes.where_to_find: Gure Toki (tucked in Plaza Nueva corner, award-winning pintxos)

signature_drinks.name: Txakoli
signature_drinks.description: Lightly sparkling Basque white wine with high acidity and low alcohol, traditionally poured from height to aerate.
signature_drinks.how_locals_drink_it: Poured dramatically from above head-height to create bubbles and aerate the wine. Perfect with pintxos, especially seafood. The theatrical pouring is part of the experience.

signature_drinks.name: Kalimotxo
signature_drinks.description: Red wine mixed with cola - sounds weird, tastes surprisingly good. A Basque invention that's now popular across Spain.
signature_drinks.how_locals_drink_it: Mixed 50/50, served over ice. Popular with younger crowds and at festivals. While it sounds like sacrilege, locals swear by it as a refreshing drink for hot days.

food_culture_notes: Pintxos cost â‚¬2-5 each and are meant to be eaten with hands while standing at the bar
The txikiteo (pintxo bar crawl) is a Friday/Saturday night ritual - groups hop from bar to bar tasting various dishes
Plaza Nueva in the Old Town is pintxo central, but locals also love the Ribera Market area
Bilbao has three Michelin-starred Azurmendi nearby, but the soul of Basque food is in pintxo bars
